body: Patch added to SVN, see 6c098b0e03c42a372af5b75e7ea5635ee58c29e0
Integrated in https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/JENA-520 and https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/JENA-521 with additional fixes by @afs
Has been applied in svn source

Hm, forget about this pull request.
I could answer my own question (see above) by going an easier way (i.e. inferencing and then merging the models, s.: https://github.com/lobid/lodmill/commit/954adb03e2bfae58974b72ed02f00e93bc147898 ).
This is recorded as a patch on https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/JENA-650.

Hi there - have you looked at Fuseki2? 

We'll probably have Fuseki1 and Fuseki2 at the same time , and there is no reason not to have multiple interfaces for different deployment situations.  Fuseki2 focuses on admin functions not available in Fuseki1.

https://github.com/apache/jena/tree/master/jena-fuseki2

(ad hoc builds in http://people.apache.org/~andy/fuseki2/, soon to be SNAPSHOT builds)

Haven't gotten fuseki2 working (lots of maven mismatches between pom versions). Tried on 2.12.2.
Will fuseki2 be the full replacement of fuseki1?

Fuseki2 should build or see http://people.apache.org/~andy/fuseki2/ where there is an unofficial build.

Or if you let me know of any build problems, I'll fix them. It should "just build(tm)".

Yes, the plan is Fuseki2 replaces Fuseki1.  It has security, an admin UI (more to be done there but the framework is in place and some basic operations), admin and UI JSON-based API to the server, there is a WAR build, better support for running as a service and it will be possible to dynamically add and delete databases on a running server.

It is compatible with Fuseki1 as a SPARQL server;  replacement will not be immediate because peopel wil need time to switch their system investements.

Compilation problems were probably caused by a maven proxy.

About fuseki1: In that case updating this interface (or making it consistent with fuseki2) would be a wasted effort, considering the move to fuseki2. (i.e. you can ignore this pull request) From my side luckily not a complete waste of effort (we're using the 'pretty' fuseki1 for the semweb classes at the VU University)

About fuseki2: mind if I give it a go to update the SPARQL interface? (using YASQE and YASR)

I tried YASGUI - nice!

There a SPARQL editor (based on qonsole) but that's not fixed. The Fuseki2 console is tied into knowledge about the available server endpoints.

(Minor: If YASQE and YASR could put a LICENSE file in their github projects, that would be perfect; next best is in the README.  I had to look in package.json to find a link to http://yasgui.org/license.txt.The old sites have a "license.txt".  Or I might have missed the obvious.)

Could you give examples of the knowledge the console uses?

And I tried running fuseki2, but the webapp won't start (error: no server running). Running the regular jena server on port 3030 doesnt help. Do you have some documentation on how to set things up, or do you recommend taking a look when things have smoothed out?

About the license: good point, added to the repo's and updated the package.json's

There is some incomplete, draft documentation:
e.g.
http://people.apache.org/~andy/fuseki2/docs/fuseki-run.html
and other files in that directory. 

You can start it like Fuseki1 (java -jar fuseki-server.jar  --mem --update /ds) and go to http://localhost:3030  It should look (very) different to Fuseki1.  Beware of browser caching.
Fuseki2 has been moved the main codebase now - module jena-fuseki2, and the document (partial draft ATM) is at http://jena.staging.apache.org/documentation/fuseki2/

Excellent, good to know, thanks. I'm currently making some improvements which I'd like to finish before incorporating it in jena (most importantly: get the file size down, as 450k is a bit too bloated)

It is the https://builds.apache.org/user/rvesse/my-views/view/Jena/job/Jena_Development_Deploy/ build which does a full build that will trigger the RAT checks

Of course it is possible to trigger them yourself locally by either specifying the `verify` goal explicitly or specifying another goal such as `package` or `install` which implies the `verify` goal.

I had all the RAT checks passing nicely at the end of last week across all modules as far as I was aware, while I am happy to merge these fixes in it'd be useful to know exactly what goal combination triggered them.

Yes - since August 2013.

That explains it.. as it would not have been removed by `mvn clean`

A good practice is I guess to try to squeeze all those kind of temporary outputs into `target/` or `/tmp` - it looks like the build is generally better behaved now.

I changed it to `jena-osgi` as that is a more common naming style.  Also avoided re-packaging other OSGi libraries like `org.apache.thrift` and `commons-lang3`.

I added excludes for httpclient, as the httpclient-osgi also depends on it directly - hence this POM would also depend on it. (They don't use the `<scope>provided</scope>` trick).
Note for later - when jsonld-java 0.5.1 or newer is released, revert cfb8a1ad1128ca0c4fa2a901f26fa9986858c502.

Andy Seaborne  on dev@jena.apache.org replies:

Having one bundle for Jena makes a lot of sense as we build and release 
whole systems, so partial replacement of bits and pieces isn't 
supported/encouraged anyway.  Releases may change cross module 
assumptions.  Personally, I'd drop SDB from the included modules; it's 
being made a maven-only module next time, and not in the distribution 
binaries.

What I'd really, really like is for this to be tested by other OSGi 
users.  As far as I know, none of the committers use OSGi day-to-day 
(we/Epimorphics used to but when we looked at the costs/benefits we 
switch to a simpler, service architecture style).

Stain - what would you say to advertising this on users@ (and 
dev@clerezza?) and seeing if we can get some user testing and validation?

```
Andy
```

Latest patch now deployed on 
http://repository.mygrid.org.uk/artifactory/ext-snapshot-local/org/apache/jena/jena-osgi/2.12.2-SNAPSHOT/
http://repository.mygrid.org.uk/artifactory/ext-snapshot-local/org/apache/jena/jena-parent/

for testing.

I now tried to made sure the POM does depend on all the OSGi bundle dependencies, and do not depend on the embedded dependencies. To do that I had to add explicitly those OSGi-dependencies of the other jena modules - so I have promoted up some new  version properties to `jena-parent` to ensure they are consistent.

JSON-LD Java will be OSGi from 0.5.1 or later - once that is out, and is used as another explicit dependencies, the Jackson dependencies can be removed (they would be implied by).

=?UTF-8?Q?Reto_Gm=C3=BCr?=  on dev@jena.apache.org replies:
Hi Stian,

If I understood and remember correctly the problem are circular
dependencies between jena artifacts and packages occurring in multiple
jars. I'm sure Minto (CC) can tell you the reasons more.

If providing OSGi bundles becomes part of Jena then maybe the root cause of
requiring this rather ugly dynamic imports and split-packages can be
addressed. This is likely to be beneficial to the overall design.

Cheers,
Reto

Minto van der Sluis  on reto@apache.org replies:
Hi,

If I recall correctly it is required due Jena using dynamic class
loading (Class.forName). Doing a grep on my "not updated in a long time"
checkout reveals 38 occurrences.

If Jena is considering to provide OSGi bundles maybe then reconsider
using an alternative for dynamic class loading.

Regards,

Minto

Mark Feblowitz  on dev@jena.apache.org replies:
In looking at the posted OSGi bundle I notice some items that we decided =
not to include in ours:

```
xercesImpl-2.11.0.jar
xml-apis-1.4.01.jar
```

For reasons having to do with differences between Oracle Java and IBM =
Java, and also issues with development on Macs, we decided to have these =
be resolved in other ways.

Now, on to the meat of the issue: what, if anything, needs to be done =
with the provided jar to prepare it for use?

I=E2=80=99ve dropped it into place, as is, and am seeing terrible things =
:-S  - basically, many of the core dependencies look to have been =
exported for subsequent import. I was able to confirm this, to some =
extent, by unjar=E2=80=99ing and loading the bundle into eclipse. There =
are quite a few unsatisfied exports.

Any suggestions?

Thanks,

Mark

Rob Vesse  on dev@jena.apache.org replies:
Yes longer term (and now we have moved to Java 7) it would be best to
avoid dynamic class loading where possible and use the Java 7
ServiceLoader paradigm instead.

Some of the existing stuff is because of the existing module structure
meaning that it is actually preferable to use the ARQ implementations over
some things in Jena Core (e.g. readers and writers) but the module
structure means Jena-Core can't guarantee the presence.  We have talked
about restructuring the modules longer term (I.e. Jena3) which would also
resolve some of this kind of problem and avoid any need for ServiceLoader
or dynamic class loading in places

However there will likely still be some places where dynamic class loading
would need to remain e.g. Jena assembler, use of java: URIs for extension
functions because they are useful features

Rob

Stian Soiland-Reyes  on dev@jena.apache.org replies:
First of all, I don't know if you are testing mine or Mark's bundle..
 I'll assume mine  from

http://repository.mygrid.org.uk/artifactory/ext-snapshot-local/org/apache/j=
ena/jena-osgi/2.12.2-SNAPSHOT/jena-osgi-2.12.2-20141101.003350-4.jar

I stated in my longer email
(http://mail-archives.apache.org/mod_mbox/jena-dev/201411.mbox/browser)
that you also need to have these OSGi bundles added:
- org.apache.httpcomponents:
  httpclient-osgi:jar:4.2.6
- org.apache.httpcomponents:httpcore-osgi:jar:4.2.5
- com.fasterxml.jackson.core:jackson-core:jar:2.3.3
- com.fasterxml.jackson.core:jackson-databind:jar:2.3.3
- com.fasterxml.jackson.core:jackson-annotations:jar:2.3.0
- org.apache.commons:commons-csv:jar:1.0
- org.apache.thrift:libthrift:jar:0.9.1
- org.apache.commons:commons-lang3:jar:3.1
- org.slf4j:jcl-over-slf4j:jar:1.7.6
- org.slf4j:slf4j-api:jar:1.7.6
- org.slf4j:slf4j-log4j12:jar:1.7.6
- log4j:log4j:jar:1.2.17

I embedded those two, xerces and xml-apis, as I could not find
official OSGi versions of them. Do you know of any? If not then they
will have to be assumed to "magically exist on the system classloader"
which is not ideal.

Perhaps:

<groupId>org.apache.xerces</groupId>
<artifactId>com.springsource.org.apache.xerces</artifactId>
<version>2.9.1</version>

http://repository.springsource.com/maven/bundles/external/org/apache/xerces=
/com.springsource.org.apache.xerces/2.9.1/com.springsource.org.apache.xerce=
s-2.9.1.jar

but it would mean adding a springsource maven repository - perhaps
this is OK within the jena-osgi module only?

The magic of the OSGi bundle Maven plugin is not quite to my liking,
so I can get that it would put some rubbish import/exports - like Jena
has 200 packages with cross-usage, so that is exposed by just looking
at the method signatures, e.g. it generates:

com.hp.hpl.jena.reasoner.transitiveReasoner;uses:=3D"com.hp.hpl.jena.graph,=
com.hp.hpl.jena.rdf.model,com.hp.hpl.jena.reasoner,com.hp.hpl.jena.util.ite=
rator";version=3D"2.12.2"

which in a way makes sense, given that

https://jena.apache.org/documentation/javadoc/jena/com/hp/hpl/jena/reasoner=
/transitiveReasoner/TransitiveEngine.html

and friends accept and return objects from those other packages. So if
you, outside Jena, wants to use transitiveReasoner, you need to also
have those other Jena packages.

Now, half of these packages might not need to be exported at all - the
plugin just ignores those that are called .impl -- but I don't know
enough about the structure to know which other packages in Jena can be
barred from exported (e.g. implementation only packages).

Which imports were not satisfied? How did you add them in Eclipse? I
can try to reproduce.
not to include in ours:
a, and also issues with development on Macs, we decided to have these be re=
solved in other ways.

A bit overdue, but I've created a new pull request for the fuseki2 version (see https://github.com/apache/jena/pull/11) . I assume we can close this one

@LaurensRietveld, Sorry for the delay in looking at this.

I have managed to apply it locally successfully and it looks very good.  I have some issues with browser caches (not a problem with the pull request!) making it tricky to be certain but when I go to the "edit" tab, which is supposed to be for editting graph data, I see a SPARQl query.

@afs no problem. This wasn't a caching issue though. YASQE was overwriting the default values of CodeMirror (instead of copying them).
I've fixed this in YASQE (and included this newest version in the pull request)
Where are we on this?

I think the main remaining question was which modules are in,.. `jena-tdb` is important, so it should be in - `jena-sdb` we can perhaps leave out as a legacy? (JDBC and OSGi adds other challenges..). I'll update this branch (and avoid the merge conflict) for this.

We might need some way to test it through OSGi - perhaps there are some Jena integration tests that I can try to run through OSGi? It could just be an Eclipse project without Maven and adding the bundles manually.
Recorded as JENA-823. Mentioning [JENA-823] will cause the JIRA to have a comment.

The module in apache-jena-libs? That includes jena-tdb, excludes legacy jena-sdb.

If there is someway to set up a Jenkins job to test the OSGi integration, the project can have that running all the time and publishing the artifacts.  I don't know the best way to do that, not using OSGi day-to-day.

I'd like to integrate this into the codebase.  (The main JIRA item blocking Fuseki2 going from "beta" designation to 2.0.0 has been fixed.)

Some discussion point for this after using it for a while:
- I like "raw response" and the ability to download is great - would it be possible to have choice of content type? Sometimes, what the developer needs to work with is fixed by other parts of the toolset.
- As a development admin tool, I wonder if being more explicit about RDF terms in the results table: e.g. `_:` to indicate bNodes, `""` on strings, `<>` for URIs.  This is a style matter; as a debugging aid, bringing out the kind of term might be useful.
- Is it possible to have a variable width results table?
- When looking at it in the context of the Fuseki2 UI, there are differnces of style and approach. The iconograph is black whereas the rest of the Fuseki2 UI is coloured with text.  In context, the execute button looks like a "go right" arrow.  Is this configurable?

In an ideal world, both the current display and this improved one woudl be in the code base. It is insurance for the future development of either (as a project, we think in terms of stability over years).  How hard would that be (sorry - Im not a strong javascript/UI developer)? Not as a user choice, but as a relative simple (documented in the code, not the website) way to switch.

- About the content types:
  To be able to download different raw response content type, we'd need to set the content type of YASQE dynamically. This is pretty easy to do: we can just add a dropdown menu with some content types. Selecting a content type from the dropdown menu (and executing the query again), will show the proper results. 
  An alternative would be to use the new YASGUI version (see http://beta.yasgui.org), a client-side lib as well, which supports modifying request parameters. But: this is pretty beta though, so if you're keen on using that one, I'd postpone this until it is a bit more stable.
- About explicit RDF terms: This is pretty easy. I'll add that
- About the variable width: The table plugin (which uses the datatables library) tries to automatically determine the 'best' dimensions. There might be a plugin which allows the user to resize the columns though (http://www.bacubacu.com/colresizable/). I'll check whether that one works nice with the datatables lib.
- I could easily simply make a backup of the old Not sure about how to approach this, but I understand your point. I'll check it out.

ps. The new YASR version (http://yasr.yasgui.org) has some new outputs: a pivot table, and google charts. There are some considerations to keep in mind though:
- the size of the fuseki UI dependencies will increase as well. Particularly when you want to include the D3js pivot plugin (used for a treemap), or when you'd like to include google charts
- The google charts is impossible to package. These charts are drawn by fetching some JS files from the internet. I.e., this is an external dependency, which does not work when fuseki is running on localhost and offline.

Could you let me know whether you'd like to include these two new plugins, and if so, whether you'd like to include D3 and/or google charts as well

I updated the PR (force-update). What changed:
- Updated the YASQE/YASR versions
- Included the pivot library, but excluded the D3 and Google Chart visualizations. One issue w.r.t. the pivot table: it requires a lot of space. So it will currently span and take as much space as it needs. No real solution to this, either than accepting it, disabling the plugin, or simply increasing the width of the interface
- Added configuring accept headers
- Added resizeable table columns
- Made RDF terms more explicit

And I see I forgot about your icon comment. The options you have are:
- If you care about the color, you can use the 'fill' css attribute to change the icon color of the SVG
- If you have the SVG string of another icon, you could replace the icon with a JS one-liner
- Or, the option is to disable the YASQE query button (set showQueryButton to false on yasqe initialization), and add a button of your own somewhere in the interface. All that button needs to call is `yasqe.query()`

I've been thinking a bit on how to approach the fallback option. How to approach this depends on the desired fallback:
- If it is a simple text area and plain html table, I suggest not going through the troubles: creating html/js which does this is easy, and can as well be easily implemented if you opt for the fallback. Not implementing the fallback now, will keep the current implementation clean
- If you'd like the old qonsole as a fallback, is there a reason not to simply use git and revert this pull request?

Looks great. I'm +1 to merging this PR into master.

I'll do a development build soon and see if we can get people to try it out. It's about time to get as much feedback as possible.

On the point about Google Chart visualization: Fuseki gets used in environments where contacting a 3rd party service is not acceptable, let alone possible. Even if the feature isn't used, it would make it unacceptable to install it.  Maybe we need to have an "extra" or "add-on" mechanism.

I have encountered a couple of Firefox-isms (v34.0, Ubuntu packaging). These do not show up in Chromium 39.0.2171.65. 
-  There is no "Execute button" showing
-  There is alignment error in the SPARQL Endpoint box

Thank you for all the work here.

Changes applied as is so we can take this as the new working base line.
Closing. Will try to find another way to fix the issue. I'll try to include some Javadocs to the method to document about the "--" and "-" special treatment.
Ah, looks like the other issues are quite small. I'll submit a new PR to fix these in a bit
related to the original PR https://github.com/apache/jena/pull/11 , where we added the YASQE and YASR libraries

Thanks.  

Just to let you know:

The Fuseki2 code has just been reorganised into multiple maven modules.  The webapp is now in jena-fuseki2/jena-fuseki-core but the structure is unchanged.  It's easy to fix up the PR from its patch.

I've added `jena-osgi-test` which tests use of jena-osgi as an OSGi bundle from within both Equinox and Apache Felix.

It has a couple of [simple tests](https://github.com/stain/jena/blob/f3535fc391df8a7b91bd988d8f4920196956bf7a/jena-osgi-test/src/main/java/org/apache/jena/osgi/test/JenaOSGITestImpl.java) that try to cover the areas of jena-iri, jena-core, jena-arq and jena-tdb. All tests pass on both frameworks.

As a side effect, in `jena-osgi-test/target/eosgi-dist` you get a pre-made set of bundles for using Jena within OSGi for the two frameworks. 

```
stain@biggie-utopic:~/src/jena/jena-osgi-test/target/eosgi-dist$ ls felix/lib

felix/lib:
commons-csv-1.0.jar        jcl-over-slf4j-1.7.6.jar          org.everit.osgi.dev.testrunner.junit4-3.0.4.jar
commons-lang3-3.3.2.jar        jena-osgi-2.12.2-SNAPSHOT.jar         org.ops4j.pax.tipi.hamcrest.core-1.3.0.1.jar
httpclient-osgi-4.2.6.jar      jena-osgi-test-2.12.2-SNAPSHOT.jar    org.ops4j.pax.tipi.junit-4.11.0.1.jar
httpcore-osgi-4.2.5.jar        jsonld-java-0.5.1.jar             slf4j-api-1.7.6.jar
jackson-annotations-2.3.0.jar  libthrift-0.9.2.jar           slf4j-log4j12-1.7.6.jar
jackson-core-2.3.3.jar         log4j-1.2.17.jar
jackson-databind-2.3.3.jar     org.everit.osgi.dev.testrunner-4.0.3.jar
```

..  you won't need the `org.everit.*`,  `jena-osgi-test-2.12.2-SNAPSHOT.jar`, `org.ops4j.pax.tipi.hamcrest.core-1.3.0.1.jar` and `org.ops4j.pax.tipi.junit-4.11.0.1.jar` in production - as they are only used here for testing.

Stian Soiland-Reyes  on dev@jena.apache.org replies:
So I have updated the jena-osgi pull request in
https://github.com/apache/jena/pull/10/

As commented there - it now includes a new module jena-osgi-test to
test it within Equinox and Apache Felix (two of the leading OSGi
frameworks).

The tests are run as part of the maven build - any failure would be
propagated out. It has to be in a separate module in order to test
calling from 'another' OSGi module.

Note that the test depends on the maven plugin

https://github.com/everit-org/eosgi-maven-plugin

This is licensed under LGPL. This is only used during the test/build
(of jena-osgi-test) - which I believe should be acceptable according
to:

https://www.apache.org/legal/resolved.html#prohibited

Given these brief tests working (which cover jena-core, jena-arq and
jena-tdb), I would be comfortable to put it in, then wait for
feedback. Perhaps wait with promoting it on the website before we know
it works generally?

I tried putting it into Clerezza instead of their
org.apache.clerezza.ext.jena.\* modules, but I am not knowledgeable
enough about how to get Clerezza started as an OSGi application..

If you want to copy-paste it into a running OSGi setup, then have a look in

```
jena/jena-osgi-test/target/eosgi-dist/felix/lib
```

as it would contain the bundles you need. Namely:

commons-csv-1.0.jar
commons-lang3-3.3.2.jar
httpclient-osgi-4.2.6.jar
httpcore-osgi-4.2.5.jar
jackson-annotations-2.3.0.jar
jackson-core-2.3.3.jar
jackson-databind-2.3.3.jar
jcl-over-slf4j-1.7.6.jar
jena-osgi-2.12.2-SNAPSHOT.jar
jsonld-java-0.5.1.jar
libthrift-0.9.2.jar
log4j-1.2.17.jar
slf4j-api-1.7.6.jar

You might not want this if you do slf4j in another way:

slf4j-log4j12-1.7.6.jar

You should not need these as they are only used for the testing:

org.ops4j.pax.tipi.junit-4.11.0.1.jar
jena-osgi-test-2.12.2-SNAPSHOT.jar
org.everit.osgi.dev.testrunner-4.0.3.jar
org.everit.osgi.dev.testrunner.junit4-3.0.4.jar
org.ops4j.pax.tipi.hamcrest.core-1.3.0.1.jar

Agreed!

I went for just jena-osgi as that is the naming style used by other Apache
projects that do separate OSGi bundles, like httpclient-osgi.

There's more to be done - ideally the jena-\* should be OSGi bundles
themselves - we might be able to adapt the headers used by Clerezza and see
how it works. I am however currently more comfortable about my jena-osgi
proposal, just to get something out there, and to avoid messing about with
the dependencies of the core Jena packages at this point.

Stian Soiland-Reyes  on dev@jena.apache.org replies:
I'm sorry, it is difficult to make a pull request be compatible with
other pull request as I can't tell in advance the merge order, and I
didn't want the file renames to go the wrong way around.

If you want I can recreate #24 from scratch now that you have merged
the #21 and #23. (Thank you!). You don't need the close #24 as I can
do an evil git push --force.

Or we can just let the dual-modules jena-osgi and jena-osgi-test stay
for the 2.13.0 release.

The idea of #24 was not to add a OSGi binary distribution build
(although it would leave an obvious place for it), it just reorganized
the modules as you suggested.

So for NOTICE/LICENSE, we can do that as a separate thread, although I
thought the stub from #22 would be sufficient for now as it covers
exactly the content of the bundle JAR (*.jena, xerces and xml-apis),
and the NOTICE file of apache-jena/ is also done manually. (which does
lead to a maintenance problem, I agree).

To generate NOTICE automatically by Maven can be done, but I'm not
very skilled in the magic here - perhaps others know more. For
jena-osgi the challenge is to play with those scopes so that it's
picks up the correct licenses - we don't want to declare any NOTICE
for say HTTP Components as that is an external dependency that is not
included in the bundle binary.

Part of #31

No, the imports can't be enforced.. (without applying the checkstyle plugin) but the above is what the default Eclipse Import Reorganize gave me :). It would hopefully give more reasonable compile errors if at a later xerces upgrade the classes disappeared.

`XSDGenericType` moved up from `xsd.impl` so that it is able to access the now private constructor of `xsd.XSDDatatype`. I didn't want to make it a top-level class at `xsd` as that would 'promote' it a bit too much. The inner class `XSDGenericType` could (should?) be made private as well, but then you can't do `instanceof` checks against it.

Thanks for pointing out [CacheLRU](https://github.com/apache/jena/blob/master/jena-arq/src/main/java/org/apache/jena/atlas/lib/cache/CacheLRU.java) which I missed.

I have now looked into this, and moving CacheLRU would mean also moving its interface [Cache](https://github.com/apache/jena/blob/master/jena-arq/src/main/java/org/apache/jena/atlas/lib/Cache.java),  `ActionKeyValue` and `CacheImpl`.

If these go into a new package, e.g. `org.apache.jena.lib.cache`, then for theit is easy to make `@deprecated` subclasses/subinterfaces for `Cache`, `CacheLRU` and even `CacheImpl`. It is trickier for `ActionKeyValue` which is more wide-spread in use within Atlas - unless I do some kind of proxy.

So that hints to me that I would have to rather let them stay in the same package, but live in `jena-core`. This would work -- but it would either make a nasty split of that package across two Maven modules -- or the whole of `atlas.lib.*` moves over.

Moving/fixing/etc CacheLRU is sounding more and more like something to reorganize in Jena 3 - Can we have a Fix for Version 3.0 in Jira that we can put something like this against?

Now simply adding the Guava dependency sounds like a much easier path!

Pull Request now no longer includes the java-sizeof test dependency - I would suggest go ahead to merge it until we don't get in the guava patch. (I'll try that afterwards - but can't commit too much time)

([license is Apache license btw](https://github.com/dweiss/java-sizeof/blob/master/pom.xml))
Also.. what semantic versioning should the jena-shadowed-ext  itself use?? :)

... or - we could just shadow Guava directly inside jena-core - the effect would be the same, but no need for an additional JAR, and thus no need to bump minor version number. Anything in Jena (except jena-iri) would then still be able to see/use the shaded Guava.
